title: Teams channel notification
content:
You can integrate Service Management with Microsoft Teams (MS Teams) in two ways:
  • Using the Built-in Solution introduced in version 1
  • Using the Integration Studio capability introduced in version 2
Both options allow agent users to collaborate in MS Teams while adhering to your established governance processes.

Sample use cases

The following typical use cases show how this integration can benefit your organization. This list is not exhaustive - the integration supports several more scenarios.

Major incident

The Major incident use case enables agent users to work together on major incidents, helping resolve critical issues quickly. The integration provides the following capabilities:

  • Incident notifications: Notifies key stakeholders in Microsoft Teams as soon as a major incident record is created, ensuring the right people are connected.
  • Stakeholder collaboration: Stakeholders can view incident details, collaborate on resolution, and close the record directly in Teams.
  • Discussion tracking: All related discussions are stored in the incident , enabling other analysts to reuse solutions later through suggested resolutions or knowledge management.

Example:

Virtual CAB

The Virtual CAB use case allows the system to notify Change Advisory Board (CAB) members about changes that are pending approval. This integration provides the following capabilities for change management:

  • CAB notifications: Notifies Change Advisory Board (CAB) members in Microsoft Teams about changes pending approval.
  • Collaborative review: CAB members can review and discuss the change process directly in Teams.
  • Comments tracking: Comments made in Teams are attached to the change request, ensuring decisions from CAB meetings are tracked.
  • Approval or rework actions: The Change Manager can approve or rework the change.

Example:

Contract negotiations

The Contract negotiations use case allows the system to send a notification to MS Teams when a contract is about to expire. This integration provides the following capabilities for contract management:

  • Expiration notifications: Sends a notification in Microsoft Teams when a contract is about to expire, ensuring timely awareness.
  • Stakeholder collaboration: Enables stakeholders to start discussions about the contract in Teams well before the expiration date.
  • Decision tracking: Decisions documented in Teams are tracked in the contract record, allowing the contract owner to proceed accordingly.

Comparison version 1 vs version 2

From a use case perspective, version 1 and Version 2 work the same way. Both versions can:
  • Send a message to a Microsoft Teams channel.
  • Listen to replies and attach them to the corresponding record in Service Management.
The differences lie in the underlying technology used by each version. The following table provides an overview of the feature set for each version.
Feature / Capability Version 1 Version 2
Difficulty level to setup Low Medium
Allows administrators to view the execution history of the integration No Yes
Possibility to create adaptive cards or modify existing ones No Yes
Level of Integration Studio DSL support Partial Full
Ability to subscribe to MS teams channels to handle replies Yes Yes
Ability to handle selected replies using outbound webhooks from MS teams
 No Yes
To summarize, version 2 enables customers to take advantage of Integration Studio capabilities. For example:

  • Provides more flexibility to expand the out-of-the-box adaptive cards sent to Microsoft Teams channels.

  • Allows customers to attach only relevant replies to the record in Service Management, instead of attaching all replies as in Version 1.

Overview

To set up the integration, connect Service Management to MS Teams and configure one or more scenarios as needed.

Setting up the integration involves the following tasks:

  1. Create a user account to activate in Entra ID
  2. Create the teams and channels
  3. Create an integration in Service Management

The tasks are explained in detail  in the following sections.

Prerequisites

Before you proceed, make sure that you have met the following prerequisites:

  • Azure Admin rights
  • An existing tenant in the Azure Active Directory (Azure AD)
  • An environment that meets the network requirements required for bi-directional communications between Service Management and MS Teams

Create a user account for the integration

We recommend that an Azure Admin creates a dedicated MS Teams integration user for the integration with Service Management. Service Management connects to MS Teams with this user. 

Here are some guidelines for your reference when creating users on Azure:

  1. Sign in to the Azure Portal with your Azure account.
  2. Click Users to create a standalone Azure Active Directory user with the type of Member. This is the integration user that will invoke the Microsoft Graph API. 
  3. Add a Microsoft Teams license to this user. This user can't log on to Teams without a license.​

     Create teams and channels

    Use the newly created MS Teams integration user, to start to create the teams and channels required for the collaboration use cases in MS Teams. 

    1. Log in to https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-teams as the MS Teams integration user, created above.
    2. Create one or more teams and channels for this integration. The channels can belong to different teams or the same team, but each channel must have a unique name. Service Management will send notification messages to and retrieve replies from these channels.
    3. For each channel, on the Channel settings tab, set Channel moderation to On. When you turn on moderation for a channel, only the team owner (the MS Teams integration user) can start new posts in that channel and regular users in the channel can only reply to existing posts and can't create new posts.
    4. Invite all stakeholders to each team.

    Create a dedicated integration user in Service Management

    When retrieving replies from MS Teams to the Discussions tab of a record, the integration displays each reply as a comment submitted by the same person. You need to create a dedicated user for this purpose. In a later step, you'll need to specify the user principal name (UPN) of this user.

    We recommend creating an integration user as follows:

    1. Log in to Suite Administration as suite-admin: https://<External Access Host>/bo.
    2. Click Users and then create a user of the Integration user type. We recommend using Microsoft Teams as the full name of this user so that it's easy to identify comments from MS Teams. 
    3. Click Tenants to open the Service Management tenant, and go to the Users tab to attach this user to the tenant. 
    4. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin, go to Administration > Master Data > People and click Sync to sync the integration user from Suite Administration. 
    5. Make a note of the user principal name (UPN) of the integration user. 

     Register an Service Management app on the Azure portal

    In parallel, the Azure Admin needs to register Service Management as an app in Azure and assign the correct permissions to it.  After this step, you should have the following information available:

    • An application (client) ID
    • A directory (tenant) ID
    • A client secret

    Perform the following steps on the Azure portal to register an application for the integration. 

    Register an application for the integration
    1. Open your Azure tenant. 
    2. Click App registrations on the left pane, and click New registration. The Register an application page appears. 
    3. Configure the following settings:
      1. Specify a Name. For example, Service Management. 
      2. Select Accounts in this organizational directory only (Single tenant).
      3. In the Redirect URI section, select Web from the dropdown list, and then enter a value in the following format: 
      • For version 1 use this callback url: https://<FQDN>/xie/public/v1/azure_callback. 
      • For version 2 use this callback url: https://<FQDN>/rest/<Tenant ID>/opb/oauth/callback
      Here, <FQDN> is the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) that is part of your tenant URL. It is the external access host of the suite.
    4. Click Register. 
    5. The application details page appears. You can find the Application (client) ID and Directory (tenant) ID. Make a note of the values.
    Configure a client secret for the application
    1. Click Certificates & secrets on the left pane. 
    2. In the Client secrets section, click New client secret.
    3. Enter a name, select an expiration period, and then click Add. 
    4. Make a note of the value of the client secret. Note that you won't be able to retrieve it after you perform another operation or leave this blade. 
    Configure authentication for the application
    1. Click Authentication on the left pane.
    2. For Supported account types, select the Accounts in this organizational directory only (xxxxx only - Single tenant) option.
    3. Set Allow public client flows to No.
    4. Click Save.
    Configure API permissions for the application
    1. Click API permissions on the left pane.
    2. Under Configured permissions, click Microsoft Graph.
    3. Click Delegated permissions, and then select the following permissions:
      • Channel: Channel.ReadBasic.All
      • ChannelMessage: ChannelMessage.Read.All, ChannelMessage.Send
      • Team: Team.ReadBasic.All
      • User: User.Read
    4. Click Update permissions.
    5. Click the Grant admin consent for xxxxx button, and then click Yes to confirm.

    Continue the setup by following the guide for either version 1 or version 2.
